==Political beginnings==
==Political beginnings==
â
At the age of twenty, he formed a workers [[Soviet (council)|soviet]] in [[Ejmiatsin]]. In [[1915]], Mikoyan formally joined the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (later known as the [[Bolshevik]] Party) and became a leader of the revolutionary movement in the [[Caucasus]].<ref name="SovArmenian"/> His interaction with Soviet revolutionaries led him to [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] where he was a co-editor for the Armenian language newspaper ''Social-Democrat'' (ÕÕ¸ÖÕ«Õ¡Õ¬-Ô´Õ¥Õ´Õ¸Õ¯ÖÕ¡Õ¿) and later on for the Russian-language paper ''Izvestia Bakeenskogo Soveta'' (ÐÐ·Ð²ÐµÑÑÐ¸Ñ ÐÐ°ÐºÐ¸Ð½ÑÐºÐ¾Ð³o Ð¡oÐ²eÑa).<ref name="SovArmenian"/> After the [[February Revolution|February 1917 revolution]] which toppled the Tsarist government, Mikoyan and other Bolsheviks in the Caucasus fought in Azerbaijan and along with twenty-six other [[commissar]]s, was captured and put in prison. Known as the "[[26 Baku Commissars|''Baku 26'']]", all twenty-six commissars were executed with exception of Mikoyan, with the circumstances of his survival shrouded in mystery.<ref>MacCauley, Martin. ''Who's Who in Russia Since 1900''. London: Routledge, 1997 p. 144 ISBN 0-415-13898-1</ref>
+
At the age of twenty, he formed a workers [[Soviet (council)|soviet]] in [[Ejmiatsin]]. In [[1915]], Mikoyan formally joined the [[Russian Social Democratic Labour Party]] (later known as the [[Bolshevik]] Party) and became a leader of the revolutionary movement in the [[Caucasus]].<ref name="SovArmenian"/> His interaction with Soviet revolutionaries led him to [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan]] where he was a co-editor for the Armenian language newspaper ''Social-Democrat'' (ÕÕ¸ÖÕ«Õ¡Õ¬-Ô´Õ¥Õ´Õ¸Õ¯ÖÕ¡Õ¿) and later on for the Russian-language paper ''Izvestia Bakeenskogo Soveta'' (ÐÐ·Ð²ÐµÑÑÐ¸Ñ ÐÐ°ÐºÐ¸Ð½ÑÐºÐ¾Ð³o Ð¡oÐ²eÑa).<ref name="SovArmenian"/> After the [[February Revolution|February 1917 revolution]] which toppled the Tsarist government, Mikoyan and other Bolsheviks in the Caucasus fought in Azerbaijan; he and twenty-six other [[commissar|commissars]] were captured and put in prison. Known as the "[[26 Baku Commissars|''Baku 26'']]", all twenty-six commissars were executed with exception of Mikoyan, with the circumstances of his survival shrouded in mystery.<ref>MacCauley, Martin. ''Who's Who in Russia Since 1900''. London: Routledge, 1997 p. 144 ISBN 0-415-13898-1</ref>
â
With the advent of the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], Mikoyan was made a commissar in the newly formed [[Red Army]] and continued to fight in Baku against anti-Bolshevik forces where he was wounded and was noted for saving the life of fellow future Party member, [[Sergo Ordzhonikidze]].<ref name="Timemag"/> In the same year, he was arrested by interventionist [[Britain|British]] troops in Baku but escaped. After his escape, he continued his Party work, and was one of the co-founders of the Baku soviet in 1919.<ref name="Timemag"/>
+
With the advent of the [[Russian Revolution of 1917]], Mikoyan was made a commissar in the newly formed [[Red Army]] and continued to fight in Baku against anti-Bolshevik forces. He was wounded in this fighting and was noted for saving the life of fellow future Party member, [[Sergo Ordzhonikidze]].<ref name="Timemag"/> In the same year, he was arrested by interventionist [[Britain|British]] troops in Baku, but was able to escape. Afterwards, he continued his Party work, and was one of the co-founders of the Baku soviet in 1919.<ref name="Timemag"/>
